**Secespita** is an [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") that appears in [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") and [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"). It is [chaotic](/wiki/Chaotic "Chaotic") for generation purposes, and its [base item](/wiki/Base_item "Base item") is a [knife](/wiki/Knife "Knife") made of [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Description](#Description)
- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [4 Origin](#Origin)
- [5 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

## Generation

In addition to random generation, Secespita may appear as a [sacrifice gift](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift") for chaotic characters, and is the guaranteed first sacrifice gift for the unaligned [Infidel](/wiki/Infidel "Infidel").

## Description

Secespita has a +1d8 [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") bonus, and deals +1d8 damage versus any monster that is not [nonliving](/wiki/Nonliving "Nonliving") - when killing such a monster with Secespita, a random amount of [energy](/wiki/Energy "Energy") is restored equal to a value between one and two times its [monster level](/wiki/Monster_level "Monster level") plus one. While wielded, Secespita confers [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance"), and [sacrificing](/wiki/Sacrificing "Sacrificing") a [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") on an altar with the weapon wielded improves its sacrifice value by 1⁄2 rounded down (e.g., a [unicorn](/wiki/Unicorn "Unicorn") corpse's value goes from 7 to 10).

Secespita can be combined with [Magicbane](/wiki/Magicbane "Magicbane") at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") to create [The Staff of the Archmagi](/wiki/The_Staff_of_the_Archmagi "The Staff of the Archmagi"), an artifact quarterstaff.

## Strategy

Secespita is primarily a "utility" artifact: though it can be adequate as a weapon due to its damage bonuses covering a majority of monsters you can encounter, and Infidels in particular can reach Expert [skill](/wiki/Skill "Skill") in knives, some of the more deadly monsters such as the various [zombies](/wiki/Zombie_\(EvilHack\) "Zombie (EvilHack)") are non-living. With this in mind, Secespita is best used to finish off weakened enemies for the energy gain, including any potential sacrifices.

While increasing sacrifice value has no effect on altar conversion, Secespita can make it far easier for an Infidel to pacify [Moloch](/wiki/Moloch "Moloch") at an already-converted altar should he be [angered](/wiki/Anger "Anger"): offering him a monster with a minimum difficulty of 10 while wielding it will pacify him, compared to a minimum difficulty of 15 otherwise.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Secespita](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secespita "wikipedia:Secespita")***

As indicated by the Wikipedia article used for the encyclopedia entry, the *secespita* is a long sacrificial knife composed of brass and [Cypriot](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyprus "wikipedia:Cyprus") copper (i.e., from Cyprus) that saw frequent use in the sacrificial rituals of the Roman priesthood. The root word is the Latin verb *secō*, which means "to cut" or "to amputate". A secespita's specific purpose was most likely for opening the body of an already-slain sacrificial animal to extract its entrails, a task carried out by the higher order of priests; Secespita's functions in EvilHack mirror this, including the improved sacrifice value.

While writers of the era such as the Roman historian [Suetonius](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suetonius "wikipedia:Suetonius") describe the secespita as a knife, some modern writers also interpret it as an axe, a cleaver or a [dolabra](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/dolabra "wikipedia:dolabra") (a type of axe that could double as a pick or mattock); this is based on an unconfirmed description originating from a summary of Roman grammarian [Festus's](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sextus_Pompeius_Festus "wikipedia:Sextus Pompeius Festus") work, with the summary written by historian and monk [Paul the Deacon](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_the_Deacon "wikipedia:Paul the Deacon"). Some Roman coins representing sacrificial emblems do appear to depict an axe as well.

## Encyclopedia entry

The secespita is a long iron sacrificial knife, made of brass and copper from Cyprus, with a solid and rounded ivory handle, which is secured to the hilt by a ring of silver or gold. The flamens and their wives, the flaminicae, who were priests and priestesses of the Ancient Rome, the virgins and the pontiffs made use of it for sacrifices.

\[ Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia ]
